metadata.case_name: Appellants (Gudur Anicut Ryots) v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appellants are ryots of several villages whose lands (about Ac. 4000-00) are irrigated by Gudur anicut system from Venkatagiri river through four tanks, three via channel from Gudur anicut at Ananthamadugu, one via channel from Pumbaleru anicut and direct channel irrigating Ac. 600-00.
Chennur village ryots (higher up the river) have a tank; attempted to construct anicut at Gollapalli (1 mile up) in 1929-1930 but failed.
Madras Government passed G.O. No. 2241/1 dated October 16, 1935 directing construction of anicut at Gollapalli for Chennur tank using excess flood water, with safeguards for Gudur system.

Appellants objected to 1935 G.O.; further investigation led to G.O. No. 1161 dated May 6, 1939 modifying it; masonry Chennur anicut constructed in 1944 with free portion (61 ft) and fixed portion (11.4 ft), planked only in floods after Gudur surplusing.

In 1952, State Government passed order (G.O. Ms. 53 F. and A (F.P.) dated February 15, 1952): (i) extend Chennur anicut by 46 ft, (ii) remove dam stones/planks and construct permanent masonry wall 175 ft long, (iii) raise height by 3 ft, (iv) install three vents with shutters.
Appellants alleged 1952 alterations would seriously affect their water supply from Gudur anicut system, depriving them during low supply periods.

Appellants filed suit in representative capacity for declaration that defendant has no right to alter/extend Chennur anicut, costs, further reliefs; specifically not asking for injunction as State bound to obey declaration.
State (defendant) filed written statement denying injurious effect on appellants' rights; later supplemental WS pleading s.4 of Act bars suit.
Trial court held s.4 bars suit on preliminary issue; appeal to District Judge failed; Second Appeal to AP High Court (judgment Dec 22, 1959) dismissed.
Chennur tank and appellants' four tanks are irrigation tanks under the Act.
1952 order based on Board of Revenue communication dated April 8, 1950 advising action under s.3(1).
No notice under Rule 5 published at time of suit filing; proposed action not yet taken.

legal_issues.text: True scope and effect of s.4 of Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949, which bars suits/applications for injunction to restrain exercise of powers conferred by s.3; whether it bars the present suit.
Whether proposed alterations to Chennur anicut fall within powers under s.3(1) to increase capacity or efficiency of Chennur tank.
Whether suit is effectively for injunction despite not formally seeking it.
Whether Government purported to act under s.3(1) despite no explicit mention or Rule 5 notice.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.3(1) restricted to improvements to tank (as defined s.2(d)) like raising height/width, supply channel; alterations to Chennur anicut exceed s.3(1) powers, so s.4 does not bar.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.3(1), s.2(d)

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit not for injunction (specifically disclaimed); only declaration, so s.4 (barring injunction suits) inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.4

petitioner_arguments.text: 1952 G.O. did not purport to act under s.3(1); no notice under Rule 5, so s.4 inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Rules, 1950 r.5; Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.3(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: s.3(1) ultra vires Constitution; s.4 falls with it.
Efficiency under s.3(1) means only distribution from tank itself, not upstream anicut.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.3(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Proposed alterations increase efficiency of Chennur tank by larger water supply within its capacity; measures under s.3(1) as directly related to tank.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.3(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Suit effectively seeks to restrain s.3 powers via declaration State must obey, circumventing s.4.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.4; Specific Relief Act s.42

respondent_arguments.text: 1952 order based on 1950 Board advice under s.3(1); notice under r.5 can still be published as action not taken.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 s.3(1); Rules r.5

respondent_arguments.text: Alterations will not injuriously affect appellants' rights.

court_reasoning.text: Object of Act: empower Govt to increase capacity/efficiency of irrigation tanks (preamble, long title); s.3(1) gives power to take measures for that, irrespective of area type; Chennur tank covered.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Efficiency depends on water quantity available; alterations to anicut (proximate to supply channel) increase efficiency by more water supply.

court_reasoning.text: Proposed alterations to Chennur anicut have direct/proximate relation to Chennur tank as supply channel emanates from there; not narrow construction limiting to tank/channel only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt cannot go far upriver without proximate link, but here connection direct.

court_reasoning.text: Suit in effect restrains s.3 powers via declaration State bound to obey; circumvention of s.4; declaration futile without injunction barred by s.4.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pleadings/reliefs make it suit to restrain Govt under s.3.

court_reasoning.text: 1952 G.O. based on 1950 advice under s.3(1); purport to act under s.3 clear from proceedings; r.5 notice not yet required as action pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to decide if r.5 mandatory; non-publication no bar to s.4.

court_reasoning.text: Legislative debates inadmissible for construction; 1943 Act different scope.
s.3(1) validity not raised below; cannot urge in special leave appeal.

holdings.text: Proposed alterations to Chennur anicut are measures under s.3(1) to increase efficiency of Chennur tank.
Suit barred by s.4 as effectively for injunction to restrain s.3 powers.

precedents_cited.relevance: Supreme Court ruled legislative proceedings inadmissible for construing Act.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Act, 1949 (Mad. XIX of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Govt to improve tanks; s.4 bars suits restraining s.3; applies to bar instant suit.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Irrigation Tanks Improvement Rules, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires notice publication; non-publication no bar as action pending.

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Declaration futile if injunction barred; suit effectively restrains Govt.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Irrigation Works (Repairs, Improvement and Construction) Act, 1943 (Mad. XVII of 1943)

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding s.4 of 1949 Act bars entertainment of suit as it effectively seeks to restrain exercise of powers under s.3(1); with costs. Noted High Court observations on merits unjustified.

key_quotes.text: "No Court shall entertain any suit or application for the issue of an injunction to restrain the exercise of any powers conferred on the Government by section 3."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exact terms of s.4 central to decision.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force, the Government shall have power to raise the full-tank level of any tank or to take any other measures for increasing its capacity or efficiency..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key empowering provision s.3(1); scope interpreted broadly.

key_quotes.text: "The efficiency of a tank depends in a large measure upon the quantity of Water that is available for irrigation purpose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court view adopted; justifies anicut alterations as improving efficiency.

key_quotes.text: "It would be a circumvention of s. 4 to entertain a suit of this nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
